poem:
"Requiem to the Absent Quiz Master"

Tabloid tales and trivia chiselled,
Test of mind, Christmas quizzical,
Missing things, sings Cave, and Time Lord, two,
On all Thursdays a riddle renewed.
Retired quiz master, your absence felt,
In stone tablets, your questions dealt.
No matter how distant the topic may range,
Some soul finds words to arrange.
Through holiday's haze, truth unfurls,
In this strange little game, our world whirls.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling optimistic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Missing things, Nick Cave sings, and so does Doctor Who – take the Thursday quiz The quiz master has already retired for his Christmas holidays, but before he went, he chiselled out some stone tablets with 15 vaguely topical or general knowledge questions and left some poor soul to type them up. Rest assured there will be quizzes on all the Thursdays throughout the holiday period – but they may be a little less topical". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
